select1.label: Greet client respectfully and with kindness.
Determine that client has been counseled for insertion procedure.
Take a medical history, assess for any heart disease and severity, any severe anemia, and ask about HIV status and offer testing if available.

Take a reproductive health history. Ask for and record the following information to determine if the IUCD is an appropriate choice for the client: Date of last menstrual period, menstrual interval (days) and bleeding pattern
Parity, pregnancy outcomes, and date of last pregnancy
History of ectopic pregnancy
Severe dysmenorrhea (painful periods)
Severe anemia (Hb<9 g/dl or HCT <27)
Any current unusual or purulent vaginal discharge, pain with sex, or lower abdominal pain

PelvicExamination Ensure that a high-level disinfected or sterile instrument kit, supplies, and a light source are available. Check that client has recently emptied her bladder and washed and rinsed her genital area, if necessary. Tell client what is going to be done and encourage her to ask questions. Help client onto examination table. Palpate abdomen and check for lower abdominal, especially suprapubic, tenderness and masses or other abnormalities. Drape woman appropriately for pelvic exam. Wash hands thoroughly with soap and water and dry with clean, dry cloth or air dry. Open high-level disinfected instrument pan or sterile pack without touching instruments. Put new examination or high-level disinfected surgical gloves on both hands Arrange instruments and supplies on high-level disinfected or sterile tray. Inspect external genitalia and urethral opening. Palpate Skene's and Bartholin's glands for tenderness or discharge. Note: If findings are normal (no history of pelvic problems, no unusual discharge, etc.), perform the bimanual exam first and the speculum exam second. This allows you to sound the uterus and insert the IUCD without having to reinsert a speculum. If there are potential problems (e.g., history of pelvic problems, signs/symptoms of STIs), perform the speculum exam first (to collect cultures) and the bimanual exam second. (If performing speculum exam first, remove speculum and place in 0.5% chlorine solution; otherwise, leave it in for IUCD insertion.)

Perform bimanual exam (see Note above): -Determine if there is cervical motion tenderness. -Carefully determine size, shape, and position of uterus. -Rule out pregnancy or any uterine abnormality. Check for enlargement or tenderness of adnexa.

a. Perform rectovaginal exam only if: -Position or size of uterus is questionable.
-There is a possible mass behind the uterus.
b. If rectovaginal exam is performed: -Immerse both gloved hands in 0.5% solution.
-Remove gloves by turning inside out and dispose of them
-Put on new clean examination or high-level disinfected gloves before continuing.

Perform speculum exam (see Note above): -Check for vaginal lesions or discharge. -Inspect cervix. -If purulent or abnormal discharge, obtain vaginal and cervical and/or urethral specimens for microscopic examination if indicated. (For guidance on Microscopic Examination, refer to the end of the checklist.*)
If both bimanual and speculum exams are negative, tell client what is going to be done and encourage her to ask questions.
Apply antiseptic solution two times to the cervix, especially the cervical os and vagina.
Gently grasp cervix with tenaculum (or vulsellum.)
While gently pulling on the tenaculum (or vulsellum), and without touching walls of vagina or speculum blades, gently pass the sound through the cervix to the top of the uterus.
Confirm whether the position of the uterus is anterior or posterior. Remove the sound.
Determine depth of uterine cavity.

Load Copper T 380A in sterile package*: -Partially open package and bend back white backing flaps. -Put white rod inside inserter tube ensuring that its tip touches the bottom of the IUCD. -Place package on flat surface. -Slide ID card underneath arms of the IUCD. -Hold tips of IUCD arms and push on the inserter tube to start bending arms. -When arms touch sides of inserter tube, pull tube away from the folded arms of the IUCD. -Elevate inserter tube and push and rotate to catch tips of arms in tube. -Push folded arms into inserter tube to keep them fixed in the tube. *No need to remove gloves during loading. However, if gloves were removed during loading, provider needs to put on a new pair of clean examination gloves or HLD gloves after loading.
Adjust movable flange to measurement obtained from sounding the uterus.
Remove loaded inserter tube without touching anything that is not sterile; be careful not to push the white rod toward the IUCD.
Hold blue depth gauge in horizontal position. While gently pulling on tenaculum (or vulsellum), pass loaded inserter tube through the cervix until depth gauge touches cervix or resistance is felt.
Hold tenaculum (or vulsellum) and white rod stationary in one hand.
Release arms of Copper T 380A IUCD using withdrawal technique (pull inserter tube toward you and remove the white rod).
After the arms have been released, carefully push the insertion tube upward toward the top of the uterus until slight resistance is felt.
Remove the insertion tube from the cervical canal.
Cut IUCD strings to 3–4 cm length.
Gently remove the tenaculum (or vulsellum) and place in 0.5% chlorine solution for 10 minutes for decontamination.
Examine cervix and if there is bleeding at the tenaculum (or vulsellum) puncture site(s), place cotton (or gauze) swab over bleeding and apply gentle pressure for 30–60 seconds.
Gently remove speculum and place in 0.5% chlorine solution for 10 minutes for decontamination.
Ask the client to continue to rest for until she feels ready to get dressed, or while you complete the post-insertion tasks.
Before removing gloves, place all instruments in 0.5% chlorine solution for 10 minutes for decontamination.
Dispose of waste materials such as cotton balls or gauze by placing in a leak-proof container or plastic bag.

Immerse both gloved hands in 0.5% chlorine solution. Remove gloves by turning inside out: -If disposing of gloves, place in leak-proof container or plastic bag. -If reusing surgical gloves, submerge in 0.5% chlorine solution for 10 minutes for decontamination.
Wash hands thoroughly with soap and water and dry with clean, dry cloth or air dry.
Check to be sure the client is not having excessive cramping and answer any questions.

Provide post-insertion instructions: -Type of IUCD and years of effectiveness, immediate effectiveness -When to return for follow-up (schedule visit, problems, warning signs, such as "PAINS") -Possible side effects and cautions -Use of condoms for dual protection against STIs -When the IUCD should be removed
Complete IUCD card and record in client record.
